Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Light-weight Near-optimal Stochastic Control Policies for Information Acquisition and Exploitation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Munagala will develop theoretical models for the problems of
uncertainty and imprecise information in computing and communication
systems such as wireless sensor networks and grid computers, and
design algorithms and policies to ameliorate their impact on system
performance, thereby leading to more effective larger-scale
deployments of such systems.

He will also develop algorithms for computing dynamic information
acquisition strategies in uncertain environments, that jointly
optimize the cost of acquiring more information, together with the
gain from exploiting the information to enhance system
performance. This class of problems falls within the larger area of
stochastic control theory.

It is well known that computing and storing the optimal control
policies (or strategies) needs exponential time and space. However, in
the scenarios that Dr. Munagala will investigate, the system can
tolerate certain suboptimality in the quality of planning decisions,
but the real requirement is that the policies be extremely lightweight
to compute and execute. This motivates the formulation and design of
computationally efficient approximately optimal policies for an entire
gamut of fundamental control theoretic problems.

The PI will draw upon his expertise in approximation and online
algorithms to develop new insights to address important theoretical
questions in stochastic control theory, with emphasis on information
acquisition and exploitation problems. In contrast with techniques
developed in the AI and operations research communities, the solutions
developed will have provable performance guarantees, in addition to
being efficient to implement. The novel algorithmic principles
emerging from this project will lay the foundations for developing a
fresh theory of approximate stochastic control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The goal of this project was to develop models and algorithms for optimization under uncertainty, especially in settings where resource allocation decisions need to be made sequentially. Related goals included the study of approximation algorithms for stochastic optimization problems; online algorithms for scheduling problems; and modeling social interactions with limited data. New techniques for design and analysis of simple, approximately optimal decision policies for several classes of stochastic control problems, scheduling problems, and auction design problems were developed. A common theme underlying these techniques is the use of novel linear programming formulations, and analysis using techniques such as prophet inequalities from Statistics, or dual fitting coupled with insights from Economics. In addition, several policies that are widely used in practice, such as Whittle Index for control problems, posted price schemes for auctions, Thompson Sampling for control problems, and proportional fairness for scheduling problems were analysed by developing novel mathematical techniques. Finally, models of information diffusion and polarization in online social networks were developed, and the underlying assumptions and conclusions were validated with data. 

Broader Impacts. The design of approximately optimal control policies has found audience in the Operations Research community, spurring further work there. The work on scheduling theory is currently being investigated for practical applicability in data centers. All the work from this project has been disseminated in top conferences and journals, both in Theoretical Computer Science as well as in appropriate applied venues. This award led to the development of two tutorials, one of which was in an applied venue of Databases, and the development of one course on Sequential Decision Theory. Three graduate students were supervised in this project period, two of who have followed an academic path after graduation, and one of who won the Best Dissertation Award in the CS Department at Duke. The project also supported three undergraduate students, one of who (Kshipra Bhawalkar) was a woman, and another (Peng Shi) who was a Finalist at the CRA Undergraduate Researcher Award, 2009.
